transcripts.text: So how old were you when you transitioned?
I transitioned when I was 10 years old.
Hey guys, welcome back to my channel.  So today's video is intended to be a sequel to a video that I did a few months back with a teen detransitioner named Elle.
The biggest thing that I regret is the change in my voice.

Now Elle was very open and candid about her story transitioning from a female to male and then back to female after realizing she had made one of the worst mistakes of her life and had permanently altered her body despite actually in the end not really being trans.  I'm going to link that video in the description and I highly encourage you to watch it after this video so you get a whole scope because today's video is actually going to be highlighting the opposite end of the spectrum.  i have wanted to do this video for so long but no one ever wants to come on my channel.  today we're actually talking with a young woman who transitioned at the age of 10 from male to female.  now look kids transitioning and detransitioning remains a highly contentious issue remains an issue that in my opinion is full of gray areas.  it's really not as black and white as people want to believe and as of recently the uk is actually moving to ban children transitioning.  This is coming off the heels of an unprecedented spike in children seeking out transitional surgeries and treatments, which has caused a ton of backlash.  And my intention with interviewing this happy teen transitioner is the same as it was with interviewing the detransitioner, right?  It's to help give you guys a full scope on exactly what is going on here and allowing you to make up your own minds.  So same disclaimer as I had when I interviewed Elle, please reserve any and all hate comments that you might send to this girl.  Keep in mind we are interviewing a teenager, a literal senior in high school.  And personally, I have a very maternal feeling over all the young trans people who come on my channel, as well as all the young detransitioners that come on my channel.  So definitely keep that in mind.  And without further ado, here is Emily's story.
Hi, I'm Emily Tressa.
You are a teen trans woman.  I was gonna say trans woman, I guess more so trans girl because you're still in high school.  You're a senior in high school, right?
Yeah, I turned 18 this past August.  So I guess I'm like legally a woman in that sense.  But yeah.

So let's get into it because as everyone knows that's watching this, I'm sure.  And if you don't know, you do.  I have done videos in the past being critical of underage transitioning.  And I've done interviews with detransitioners.  I did one in February with a girl named Elle who transitioned to a man and then back after she realized it was a mistake.  And as always, I mean, contrary, I think to maybe what some people think, I like to provide information.  both sides.  So I think it's only fair that we talk about the success stories as well, because I don't think it's as black and white of an issue as people think.  I think there are people who it's absolutely the right decision for them in the long run and then people who it isn't.  So I think it's only fair to show the other side of the coin, you know?  So how old were you when you transitioned?
I transitioned when I was 10 years old, socially, socially.

That is very, very young.  That's probably shocking to a lot of people, but I think it's important to note that you said socially, not necessarily medically at 10.  Right.  So when, what age were you when you started undergoing the more medical side of transitioning?

I started hormone blockers when I was 12 years old.  And for me, that was really important because I never wanted to go through male puberty.  And it was just like a pause almost because I was like, so scared.  And my doctors made sure that I was right at my Tanner two stage about to start puberty before I got blockers.  So I wasn't completely suppressed.
So you did blockers and then hormones.  at what age?  Cause people don't know hormone blockers come before hormones in general.
I started hormone hormones when I was 13.

Okay.  Yeah.  So I'm sure you noticed like a lot of changes really, really quickly upon doing that.  Right.  Cause I think even when you go on those medications as an adult, the changes are pretty quick, right?

Yeah, for me, it was so exciting because I've always just dreamt of having curves and boobs and that.  aesthetic just for me.  And when I started taking estrogen, it was like finally my inside or how I felt on the inside was matching how I look on the outside.

What age would you say that you started feeling gender dysphoria?  Because I've been very open with the fact that my earliest memories in life are that of gender dysphoria.  Really from preschool and on, I've had that feeling of a misalignment in my brain and the way I was perceived.  So when did that start for you?

A hundred percent?  around the same time for me as well, like around the age of three or four when I could like get a sense of all that.  And when I was going to preschool and especially preschool, when I saw that everything was separated by girls and boys, I've always known that I am a girl on the inside.  And I've made that very clear to my family and everyone.  just, I was so miserable and I've been so, or I was so uncomfortable with what was down there my whole life.  I remember like going up to my grandma when I was four years old, asking, like four or five asking when my penis was going to fall off like that type of thing like when am I going to become a woman?

you know that's commonplace.  I've actually spoken to quite a few trans people who have said that they would like ask their families like questions that their families probably thought were super like crazy.  but it was you know stemming from the fact that they were feeling that dysphoria at like a really young age.  so that's pretty common.  um one of the things that we bring up when we talk about um kids transitioning is obviously the importance of fertility and the fact that especially from male to female.  when you transition at a young age um i guess your age would be like the classic age of someone who when you transition at that age you're not able to reproduce later in life and that is a concern for a lot of people who are critical of kids transitioning.  um when you went through medical transition at the beginning did you have doctors that made a point to discuss that?  was that a point of interest?  how did that work?  because i'm actually curious for myself.

My hormone doctors and my endocrinologist told me that once I started hormones, that it would pretty much like stop any production of sperm down there.  And for me, I'm attracted to men.  And I figured I don't really want to save sperm or like freeze it because in the future, I'm going to want to be with a man anyway.  And ever since I was little, my mom was telling me this because I was talking to her about it.  I've always said I wanted to adopt kids and I've totally been open to that.  So I came to terms with that when I was young.  I was like, I'm totally fine with adopting kids.  I'll love that child no matter what.  Yeah, for sure.

Adoption is definitely, I mean, it's in the cards for me as well.  Even as someone who transitioned, I began at 20.  I wasn't able to save any sort of DNA.  I guess I never even really prioritize that in my mind because when you are transitioning, it's not necessarily at the forefront of your plans or your thoughts because it's so- How would you react to the-?  people who are tuned into this sort of space on YouTube have seen like a rise in the amount of like teenage transitioners coming on YouTube and making videos.  Like I said, I interviewed Elle recently and there's a bunch of others.  How do you react to people who go through transition at the age you did sometimes?  And then by the time they're 18, 19, decide that it was a mistake and come to that realization.  Like I always wonder from people who have successful child transitioning stories, how they think of those stories.

I think for me, I always try to remember that everyone's story is different, whether you're actually trans or you're just like experimenting and trying to find who you are.  In this day and age, being trans is also trendy sometimes that people might think that they're trans if they're not and go through with that.  And it's unfortunate, but that's something that also it just happens.  But I'm glad that people have been able to find who they are and come to terms with that as well and be like, I'm actually not trans and then pick up about it because that's important as well.

Yeah, I've always said, I think two things can be true at once.  I think that there's absolutely the possibility that certain people can transition as young as you did, for example, and live happy lives.  And it was the right decision for them.  I think that we need to have a better way of diagnosing and confirming for sure people having that misalignment in their brain, whatever it is.  And I feel like there needs to be a lot more research because until then, I think you're going to get the sort of duality in it where there's going to be kids who go through it.  And it was a mistake.  And I mean, specifically the girl I interviewed before, like her voice is like permanently damaged from it.  It's so sad.  So like, it's like, that can be true at the same time as people like yourself, which obviously I would never, ever doubt that it was the perfect decision for you.

I think for my specific case, since I've been so young, I've always needed like therapist letters and like doctors have made sure that I've been like consistent, persistent and insistent about this.  Like, it's not just like, was there anything when I, I've gone to therapy for years since before I transitioned too.  So I've had like records and like people to back this up as well.  That it's not just like something.

I think we have to be able to like in your story, like properly diagnose someone, really go through the steps and eliminate this fear that if you don't allow someone to transition, then it means you're transphobic.  Because I think some people it's not really right for them.  I think the one size fits all thing that never works anywhere in life.  So I can't see why it would work for people like us, you know?
I think it's really important to definitely have guidelines or regulations and things to back it up because I feel like there are also some trans people that might just like jump right into it.

I think we really need to nail down in the medical sense, exactly what being trans is, if that makes sense.  Because I feel that the definition gets so skewed and so broadened to the point where there are going to be young people who fall into it thinking that it's the right thing for them when it's really not.  So you're in high school.  Yeah.  And a lot has changed since I was in high school.  Not that I'm that old.  I'm only 26, but a lot has changed, I know.  And I'm curious to hear, you're a senior now, how your school has, are you out at school?
Yeah, I'm fully open about being trans.
That's awesome.  Where do you see your life headed?
So I'm going to college for business management as my major, and I want to continue working on my YouTube channel.
You have a YouTube channel?
Yeah, I do.
I'm going to put it on the screen.  We're going to shout out your YouTube channel right now.

Love your YouTube channel, you guys.  But I've also been working on music that I want to release.  And I have a single out now with one of my friends.  And I also want to have like my own clothing fashion brand in the future.

You are amazing.  I have such a soft spot in my heart for first of all, entrepreneurs.  And second of all, like, I don't know.  I feel like the sky's the limit for you.  I think that you have the brightest of bright futures ahead of you.  I think that you're an important voice in this conversation, which like I said, both sides definitely need to be presented because you know, it's just a, it's a topic that is still developing, you know, and I definitely appreciate you coming on.
Thank you so much for having me.

Yes, of course.  So final thoughts.  I think it was really amazing to see someone who transitioned at a young age who was successful and happy.  I've always known these cases exist.  Obviously, you have people like Kim Petras, Josh Jennings, who, for all intents and purposes from the outside looking in, seem to be happy with their choice.  And I don't really foresee them being unhappy with it in the future.  However, as I discussed with Emily, I really don't feel like the positive cases necessarily negate the negative and vice versa.  And I also think that considering Emily started her transition technically eight years ago, it was actually a different time when it came to trans issues and how trans is treated in the medical field.  It was actually medicalized, which of course activists are trying to get rid of now.  So there actually was a better way to vet people who would benefit from transition.  Whereas now, the definition has become so expanded that there are, as we've discussed and as we've interviewed, a lot of people falling into that category that don't need to be there.  i mean eight years ago in terms of trans and lgbt.  discourse might as well have been a century ago and honestly there was just more precision with diagnosing people and kids specifically with gender dysphoria than there is now.  back then you actually needed to have gender dysphoria to be diagnosed as trans and given hormones and given surgery.  Now you don't, which is why around the time that Emily transitioned, you only had 77 trans kids seeking treatment.  at the UK's most popular gender clinic.  as of 2019 that number raised from 77 to 2,000 plus with 3,000 plus on the waiting list.  so something is clearly up and it's clearly the broadening of the definition of trans.  so I really do hold true to my convictions and my opinions that I previously had on children transitioning, but I obviously of course think that it was the right move for Emily just based on our conversation.  and so I wish her all the success and happiness in the world and I'm sure she's gonna get it.  she seems like an amazing young woman.  Make sure you guys subscribe to this YouTube channel.  I know this is not the first video you've watched me.  I know you're going to watch four or five more after this.  You might as well just join the family because we are a family.  I don't have friends, so I kind of need subscribers.  Make sure you guys follow me on Twitter, Instagram, and now TikTok because I post on there way more than I do on YouTube and you got to follow those to keep up with me.  And with that being said, I'll see you guys in the next video.  Love you.
